ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I know a lot of new grammar and Korean cultural practices.
I deepened my understanding of Korean grammar, vocabulary and of the Korean culture
My korean has vastly improved.

I learned more forms of grammar and vocabulary that correlate to scenarios that students might encounter if they were to visit Korea or a Korean speaking area, and I also learned more about Korean culture that I did not have much previous knowledge about.
This course moved on from L3 Korean, providing new grammar for speaking and writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish we had a group project. I think Lim has created an amazing classroom dynamic so it would be nice to work more with my peers.
It was very complete and interesting, but I would say it lacks some organization.
Taking a language class over zoom made it very difficult to practice speaking, since we are limited in who can speak without becoming chaotic.
This was an amazing course that was both challenging but also simple enough to greatly improve my korean skills.

Breakout rooms were a great way to practice the grammar that Lim ssn had just taught or for just repeating the passages for clarity and speaking practice, and I also think that I got to meet a lot of my classmates through them too, so it was fun! I do think that it's unfortunate that it was held online, but Lim ssn still did his best and created a good environment for learning and for people to ask questions without hesitation.

Particularly given the circumstances, I think this class was brilliantly executed. The option for asynchronous learning was tried a few times and worked to great effect: in the future, it might be useful to have some asynchronous sections for review and homework purposes, particularly for vocabulary study.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breakout rooms were a nice way to get to know everyone in class.

Zoom use was very successful, as feel as asynchronous classes. I really enjoyed the use of breakout rooms to practice the language. However, engagement during lecture time could be improved, since it is difficult for students to talk in bigger zoom groups.
It might have been more helpful to make students present short dialogues more frequently.
The virtual engagement with continuous breakout rooms was very helpful to get practice and the best method with everything being virtual.

Given that this is an online class, I think that Lim ssn did the best that he could, and it helped when he sent us into breakout rooms to practice/get to know the other students and gave us time to listen to things over and over again for clarity. I think it was good that he tried to incorporate a lot of questions during his lessons to make sure that we were attentive and actively trying to answer the questions on the slides.

Writing projects and weekly posting were both helpful and fun projects. Asynchronous learning was also a useful exercise, though it probably requires a lot more planning and work to implement on a larger scale.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I always do. Its a fun and fulfilling class.

Absolutely. Lim Ssn makes such an engaging and welcoming environment. I took a big gap between L1/L2 my first year and L3/L4 my senior year, and Lim Ssn made it so easy for me to regain my confidence in speaking.
Yes! Professor Lim is amazing.
I would definitely recommend this course. We learn more about the language and culture of Korea in a very engaging way.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The course material is well organized, and the instructor made class very fun.
I would greatly recommend this course to anyone wanting to improve their Korean. The class and the instructor made Korean easy and fun to learn and improve.

Yes! I would definitely recommend for students to take this after L3. I think it is pretty similar to the format of other classes, but you do learn other forms of grammar and about Korean culture. I also think that the class environment is very fun and welcoming because at the end of it you're all just trying to learn a language together, so everyone is very nice and helpful!
I would highly recommend this course, along with the other Korean classes at Yale. They have progressed in difficulty and complexity without losing a sense of fun and community.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also did asynchronous classes sometimes on Fridays.
We had asynchronous classes every so often with virtual modules
Recorded lecture
N/A
We had live lectures/discussions in class in breakout rooms with a few asynchronous classes.
There were also weekly scheduled TA sessions.
